user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified get_nonce_timestamp code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/590.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of get_nonce_timestamp as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_nonce_timestamp:
#define NONCE_STD_LEN(digest_size) ((digest_size)*2+TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN)
...
#define MD5_DIGEST_SIZE (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*MD5_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE
...
#define TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN (TIMESTAMP_BIN_SIZE*2)
...
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint64_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint64_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT64_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
</additional code>
Judge whether the above get_nonce_timestamp code violates the rule 21.14 or not.
scenario: Using memcmp to compare null terminated strings violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. In the provided get_nonce_timestamp function code and the vicinity, there is no use of memcmp to compare null terminated strings; instead, the code uses strlen and a custom function MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ for string processing and comparison.
